title: “Let NullaryConstructor = something;” causes internal compiler error: “tried to overwrite interned AdtDef”

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-stable
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from one stable version to another.

body:
I was trying an `if let` pattern match for a nullary constructor like this:

``` rs
if let Some(::router::NoRoute) = err.error.downcast() {
    …
}
```

but the compiler choked on the pattern match in an unexpected way.  The fact that it's qualified does not seem to matter.  See minimal repro below.

---

I tried this code:

``` rs
extern crate router;
fn test() {
    let router::NoRoute = (); // NoRoute is an empty struct in “router”
}
```

I expected to see this happen:

_An plain, ordinary, not-scary type error._

Instead, this happened:

```
error: internal compiler error: src/librustc/ty/context.rs:604: Tried to overwrite interned AdtDef: router::NoRoute

note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug.
```
## Meta

`rustc --version --verbose`:

```
rustc 1.12.0
binary: rustc
commit-hash: unknown
commit-date: unknown
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.12.0
```
